simText.textData:
In the next portion of the excercise, a diode is placed in the circuit parallel to the relay coil while the relay is active. The diode is reverse-biased when supply voltage is applied. A light-emitting diode (LED) is used to show the effects the diode has on the circuit. Pay attention to it during your circuit tests.

In an LED, a small lens is built into the diode so the light can be seen. When the LED is forward-biased, it illuminates. When the LED is reverse-biased, it prevents current flow. The LED operates at about 1.5 V so a dropping resistor is needed to prevent damage to the LED.

Select Continue when you're ready to move forward.

Click the toggle switch to power up the circuit to perform a voltage measurement across the relay coil.

Click the Supporting Document button below at any time if you need information on the DMM's functions.

Select Continue when you're ready to proceed.

1. Drag and drop test leads to meter's input terminals.

2. Click on appropriate rotary setting.

3. Drag and drop test leads to coil terminals on the relay.

Note: Remove mouse pointer from test lead to have DMM operate properly.

Select Continue when you're ready to proceed.
1. Click the Range button on the DMM to select the 4000 V scale.

Good, the DMM is now set to the 4000 V scale.

Click Continue to proceed.

1. Click the MIN-MAX button on the DMM to select the record feature.

Click Continue to proceed.

1. Click the Peak MIN-MAX button on the DMM to select the 1ms time interval record setting.

Click Continue to proceed.

1. Place the cursor over the push button micro-switch on the electrical project board to operate the relay and obtain your DMM measurements.

2. Move the cursor off the micro-switch to turn off the lights.

Click Continue to proceed.

1. Observe maximum voltage reading.

2. Click the MIN-MAX button on the DMM to obtain the minimum readings.

Click Continue when you are ready to proceed.
